trans-unit.source: Represents a view for grouping, sorting, filtering, and navigating a data collection.
You should not create objects of this class in your code.

To create a collection view for a collection that only implements <xref:System.Collections.IEnumerable>, create a <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionViewSource> object, add your collection to the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionViewSource.Source%2A> property, and get the collection view from the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionViewSource.View%2A> property.

You can think of a collection view as a layer on top of a binding source collection that allows you to navigate and display the collection based on sort, filter, and group queries, all without having to manipulate the underlying source collection itself.

If the source collection implements the <xref:System.Collections.Specialized.INotifyCollectionChanged> interface, the changes that raise the <xref:System.Collections.Specialized.INotifyCollectionChanged.CollectionChanged> event are propagated to the views.
Because a view does not change the underlying source collection, a source collection can have multiple views associated with it.
By using views, you can display the same data in different ways.
For example, you can use two views on a collection of `Task` objects to show tasks sorted by priority on one part of the page and grouped by area on another part of the page.
In [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_winclient](~/includes/tla2sharptla-winclient-md.md)] applications, all collections have an associated default collection view.
Rather than working with the collection directly, the binding engine always accesses the collection through the associated view.
To get the default view, use the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionViewSource.GetDefaultView%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method.
An internal class based on <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView> is the default view for collections that implement only <xref:System.Collections.IEnumerable>.
<xref:System.Windows.Data.ListCollectionView> is the default view for collections that implement <xref:System.Collections.IList>.
<xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> is the default view for collections that implement <xref:System.ComponentModel.IBindingListView> or <xref:System.ComponentModel.IBindingList>.

Alternatively, you can create a view of your collection in [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_xaml](~/includes/tlasharptla-xaml-md.md)] by using the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionViewSource> class and then bind your control to that view.
The <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionViewSource> class is the [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_xaml](~/includes/tla2sharptla-xaml-md.md)] representation of the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView> class.
For an example, see [How to: Sort and Group Data Using a View in XAML](~/docs/framework/wpf/data/how-to-sort-and-group-data-using-a-view-in-xaml.md).
For more information, see "Binding to Collections" in [Data Binding Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/data/data-binding-overview.md).
To set a view in [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_xaml](~/includes/tla2sharptla-xaml-md.md)], use the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionViewSource> class.

<xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionViewSource> is the [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_xaml](~/includes/tla2sharptla-xaml-md.md)] representation of the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView> class, and it exposes the most commonly used members of the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView> class.
XAML Text Usage
See Remarks
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView"></xref> class that represents a view of the specified collection.
The instance of <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView> is bound to the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_ui](~/includes/tlasharptla-ui-md.md)] thread dispatcher of the caller of this constructor.
The underlying collection.

Gets a value that indicates whether a thread other than the one that created the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView"></xref> can change the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.SourceCollection"></xref>.

`true` if a thread other than the one that created the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView"></xref> can change the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.SourceCollection"></xref>; otherwise, `false`.
Gets a value that indicates whether the view supports filtering.
If this property returns `false`, setting the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.Filter%2A> property throws an exception.
`true` if the view supports filtering; otherwise, `false`.
The default is `true`.
Gets a value that indicates whether the view supports grouping.
Use this property to test whether the view supports sorting before adding <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.GroupDescriptions%2A>.
Derived classes override this property to indicate whether they support grouping.
`false` in all cases.
Gets a value that indicates whether the view supports sorting.
Use this property to test whether the view supports sorting before adding <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.SortDescriptions%2A>.
Derived classes override this property to indicate whether they support sorting.
`false` in all cases.
Clears any pending changes from the change log.
Clears unprocessed changed to the collection.
Occurs when the view has changed.
Returns an object that you can use to compare items in the view.
An <xref href="System.Collections.IComparer"></xref> object that you can use to compare items in the view.
Returns a value that indicates whether the specified item belongs to the view.
This method does not make any assumptions about whether the item belongs to the underlying collection.
If the caller knows that the item belongs to the underlying collection, it is more efficient to call the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.PassesFilter%2A> method.
The object to check.
`true` if the item belongs to the view; otherwise, `false`.
Gets the number of records in the view.
If a filter is set, this property value only includes items that pass the filter.
If the underlying collection is of type <xref:System.Collections.IEnumerable>, this is an O(N) operation.
This value is cached until the collection changes.
The number of records in the view, or –1 if the number of records is unknown.
Gets or sets the culture information to use during sorting.
The culture information to use during sorting.
Occurs after the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> has changed.
Occurs when the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> is changing.
Gets the current item in the view.
Collection views support the concept of a current record pointer.
As you navigate through the objects in a collection view, you are moving a record pointer that allows you to retrieve the object that exists at that particular location in the collection.
Note that moving the current record pointer has some interactions with any sorting or filtering that is applied to the collection.
Sorting preserves the current record pointer on the last record selected, but the collection view is restructured around it.

(Perhaps the selected record was at the beginning of the list before, but now the selected record might be somewhere in the middle.) Filtering preserves the selected record if that selection remains in view after the filtering.
Otherwise, the current record pointer is set to the first record of the filtered collection view.
The current item of the collection is bound to automatically if the target of a binding is a singleton value.
If the target is an <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl>, the current item is synchronized with the selected item.
For example, if a list box is bound to a collection, the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem%2A> is synchronized with the currently selected item.
The current item of the view.
By default, the first item of the collection starts as the current item.
Gets the ordinal position of the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> within the (optionally sorted and filtered) view.
The ordinal position of the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> within the (optionally sorted and filtered) view.
Enters a defer cycle that you can use to merge changes to the view and delay automatic refresh.
The typical usage is to create a `using` scope with this method and then place multiple view-changing calls within the scope.
This delays automatic refresh until the defer cycle is exited.
An <xref href="System.IDisposable"></xref> object that you can use to dispose of the calling object.
Removes the reference to the underlying collection from the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView"></xref>.
Use this method to unsubscribe to events on the underlying collection and allow the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView> to be garbage collected.
Gets or sets a method used to determine if an item is suitable for inclusion in the view.
Simpler implementations do not support filtering and throw a <xref:System.NotSupportedException>.
Use the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CanFilter%2A> property to test if filtering is supported before assigning this property with a non-null value.
A delegate that represents the method used to determine if an item is suitable for inclusion in the view.
The current implementation does not support filtering.
Returns an object that you can use to enumerate the items in the view.
An <xref href="System.Collections.IEnumerator"></xref> object that you can use to enumerate the items in the view.
Retrieves the item at the specified zero-based index in the view.
This method evaluates the index with any <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.SortDescriptions%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.Filter%2A> property values that are set on the view.
If the underlying collection is of type <xref:System.Collections.IEnumerable>, this is an O(N) operation.
The zero-based index of the item to retrieve.
The item at the specified zero-based index in the view.
index is less than 0.
Gets a collection of <xref href="System.ComponentModel.GroupDescription"></xref> objects that describes how the items in the collection are grouped in the view.
The value of this property is always `null` because the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView> class does not support grouping over its underlying collection.
The derived classes <xref:System.Windows.Data.ListCollectionView> and <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> do support grouping.
`null` in all cases.
Gets a collection of the top-level groups that is constructed based on the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.GroupDescriptions"></xref> property.
The value of this property is always `null` because the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView> class does not support grouping over its underlying collection.
The derived classes <xref:System.Windows.Data.ListCollectionView> and <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> do support grouping.
`null` in all cases.
Returns the index at which the specified item is located.

If this method returns an index other than -1, it must always be true that view[index-1] < item <= view[index], where the comparisons are done using the <xref:System.Collections.IComparer.Compare%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method of the view, if one exists.
This particular behavior of the method is used by some <xref:System.Collections.Specialized.INotifyCollectionChanged.CollectionChanged> event handlers to speed up reaction to insertion and deletion.
If the derived class does not override this method, a listener does a binary search using the <xref:System.Collections.IComparer.Compare%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method.
The item to locate.
The index at which the specified item is located, or –1 if the item is unknown.
Gets a value that indicates whether the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> of the view is beyond the end of the collection.
Collection views support the concept of a current record pointer.
As you navigate through the objects in a collection view, you are moving a record pointer that allows you to retrieve the object that exists at that particular location in the collection.
`true` if the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> of the view is beyond the end of the collection; otherwise, `false`.
Gets a value that indicates whether the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> of the view is before the beginning of the collection.
Collection views support the concept of a current record pointer.
As you navigate through the objects in a collection view, you are moving a record pointer that allows you to retrieve the object that exists at that particular location in the collection.
`true` if the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> of the view is before the beginning of the collection; otherwise, `false`.
Gets a value that indicates whether the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> is at the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentPosition"></xref>.

`true` if the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> is in the view and at the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentPosition"></xref>; otherwise, `false`.
Gets a value that indicates whether the underlying collection provides change notifications.
`true` if the underlying collection provides change notifications; otherwise, `false`.
Gets a value that indicates whether the resulting (filtered) view is empty.
`true` if the resulting view is empty; otherwise, `false`.
Gets a value that indicates whether any object is subscribing to the events of this <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView"></xref>.
`true` if any object is subscribing to the events of this <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView"></xref>; otherwise, `false`.
Gets a value that indicates whether there is an outstanding <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.DeferRefresh"></xref> in use.
`true` if there is an outstanding <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.DeferRefresh"></xref> in use; otherwise, `false`.
Sets the specified item to be the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> in the view.
If the specified item is not found, the method returns `false` and the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem%2A> is positioned before the beginning of the collection in the view.
Collection views support the concept of a current record pointer.
As you navigate through the objects in a collection view, you are moving a record pointer that allows you to retrieve the object that exists at that particular location in the collection.
For more information, see "Binding to Collections" in [Data Binding Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/data/data-binding-overview.md).
For more information about the current item of a view, see <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem%2A>.
The item to set as the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref>.
`true` if the resulting <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> is within the view; otherwise, `false`.
Sets the first item in the view as the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref>.
Collection views support the concept of a current record pointer.
As you navigate through the objects in a collection view, you are moving a record pointer that allows you to retrieve the object that exists at that particular location in the collection.
For more information, see "Binding to Collections" in [Data Binding Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/data/data-binding-overview.md).
`true` if the resulting <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> is an item within the view; otherwise, `false`.
Sets the last item in the view as the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref>.
Collection views support the concept of a current record pointer.
As you navigate through the objects in a collection view, you are moving a record pointer that allows you to retrieve the object that exists at that particular location in the collection.
For more information, see "Binding to Collections" in [Data Binding Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/data/data-binding-overview.md).
`true` if the resulting <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> is an item within the view; otherwise, `false`.
Sets the item after the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> in the view as the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref>.
Collection views support the concept of a current record pointer.
As you navigate through the objects in a collection view, you are moving a record pointer that allows you to retrieve the object that exists at that particular location in the collection.
For more information, see "Binding to Collections" in [Data Binding Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/data/data-binding-overview.md).
`true` if the resulting <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> is an item within the view; otherwise, `false`.
Sets the item at the specified index to be the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> in the view.
Collection views support the concept of a current record pointer.
As you navigate through the objects in a collection view, you are moving a record pointer that allows you to retrieve the object that exists at that particular location in the collection.
For more information, see "Binding to Collections" in [Data Binding Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/data/data-binding-overview.md).
The index to set the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> to.
`true` if the resulting <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> is an item within the view; otherwise, `false`.
Sets the item before the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> in the view as the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref>.
Collection views support the concept of a current record pointer.
As you navigate through the objects in a collection view, you are moving a record pointer that allows you to retrieve the object that exists at that particular location in the collection.
For more information, see "Binding to Collections" in [Data Binding Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/data/data-binding-overview.md).
`true` if the resulting <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> is an item within the view; otherwise, `false`.
Gets a value that indicates whether the view needs to be refreshed.
This property indicates if the internal state of the view has changed and requires a <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.Refresh%2A> method call.

The typical scenario is if a <xref:System.ComponentModel.SortDescription> or similar has been added to the view while the view is in a deferred refresh cycle (see <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.DeferRefresh%2A>).
In this scenario, no explicit call to <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.Refresh%2A> is needed; as soon as the deferred refresh cycle ends, the view calls refresh automatically.
`true` if the view needs to be refreshed; otherwise, `false`.
Gets the object that is in the collection to represent a new item.

When a <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView> that implements <xref:System.ComponentModel.IEditableCollectionView> has <xref:System.ComponentModel.IEditableCollectionView.NewItemPlaceholderPosition%2A> set to <xref:System.ComponentModel.NewItemPlaceholderPosition.AtBeginning> or <xref:System.ComponentModel.NewItemPlaceholderPosition.AtEnd>, the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.NewItemPlaceholder%2A> is added to the collection.
The <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.NewItemPlaceholder%2A> always appears in the collection; it does not participate in grouping, sorting, or filtering.
The <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem%2A> cannot be the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.NewItemPlaceholder%2A>.
Methods that perform relative navigation, such as the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.MoveCurrentToNext%2A>, skip the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.NewItemPlaceholder%2A>.

<xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.MoveCurrentToFirst%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.MoveCurrentToLast%2A> skip the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.NewItemPlaceholder%2A> if <xref:System.ComponentModel.IEditableCollectionView.NewItemPlaceholderPosition%2A> is set to <xref:System.ComponentModel.NewItemPlaceholderPosition.AtBeginning> or <xref:System.ComponentModel.NewItemPlaceholderPosition.AtEnd>, respectively.

Methods that perform absolute navigation, such as <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.MoveCurrentToPosition%2A>, do nothing if the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.NewItemPlaceholder%2A> would be the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem%2A>.
The object that is in the collection to represent a new item.
Returns a value that indicates whether the view can change which item is the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref>.
`false` if a listener cancels the change; otherwise, `true`.
Occurs when the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.AllowsCrossThreadChanges"></xref> property changes.
Called by the base class to notify the derived class that an <xref href="System.Collections.Specialized.INotifyCollectionChanged.CollectionChanged"></xref> event has been posted to the message queue.
The <xref href="System.Collections.Specialized.NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs"></xref> object that is added to the change log.
args is `null`.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CollectionChanged"></xref> event.
Take any sorting, filtering, or grouping criteria into consideration before calling this method to raise the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CollectionChanged> event.
The <xref href="System.Collections.Specialized.NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs"></xref> object to pass to the event handler.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CollectionChanged"></xref> event.

This method calls <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.ProcessCollectionChanged%2A> if it is on the correct [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_ui](~/includes/tla2sharptla-ui-md.md)] thread dispatcher and has never been updated from a different thread, or posts the change to the dispatcher to process it on the correct thread.
The sender of the event.
The <xref href="System.Collections.Specialized.NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs"></xref> object to pass to the event handler.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentChanged"></xref> event.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentChanging"></xref> event with the specified arguments.
Information about the event.
Raises a <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentChanging"></xref> event that is not cancelable.
This method sets <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentPosition%2A> to –1.
This method is called by collection changes that affect the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem%2A>.
Raises the <xref href="System.ComponentModel.INotifyPropertyChanged.PropertyChanged"></xref> event using the specified arguments.
Arguments of the event being raised.
Returns a value that indicates whether the specified item in the underlying collection belongs to the view.
Unlike the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.Contains%2A> method, this method assumes that the specified item belongs to the underlying collection.
This method takes filters into account.
Typically, you use this method during collection-changed notifications to determine if the added or removed item requires processing.
The item to check.
`true` if the specified item belongs to the view or if there is not filter set on the collection view; otherwise, `false`.
When overridden in a derived class, processes a single change on the [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_ui](~/includes/tla2sharptla-ui-md.md)] thread.
The <xref href="System.Collections.Specialized.NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs"></xref> object to process.
Ensures that all pending changes to the collection have been committed.
Occurs when a property value has changed.
Re-creates the view.

When you set the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.Filter%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.SortDescriptions%2A>, or <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.GroupDescriptions%2A> property; a refresh occurs.
You do not have to call the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.Refresh%2A> method immediately after you set one of those properties.
For information about how to delay automatic refresh, see <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.DeferRefresh%2A>.
Derived classes use the protected <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.RefreshOverride%2A> method to override the behavior of this method.
Refreshes the view or specifies that the view needs to be refreshed when the defer cycle completes.
Re-creates the view.

Sets the specified item and index as the values of the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> and <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentPosition"></xref> properties.
The item to set as the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref>.
The value to set as the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentPosition"></xref> property value.

Sets the specified item and index as the values of the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> and <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentPosition"></xref> properties.
This method can be called from a constructor of a derived class.
Call this overload from constructor of a derived class.
Do not pass the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.Count%2A> property, which is a virtual property, as `count`.
Instead, pass the count of the internal <xref:System.Collections.IList> that represents the collection.
<xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.SetCurrent%2A> is introduced in the .NET Framework version 3.5.
For more information, see [Versions and Dependencies](~/docs/framework/migration-guide/versions-and-dependencies.md).
The item to set as the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref>.
The value to set as the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentPosition"></xref> property value.
The number of items in the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView"></xref>.
Gets a collection of <xref href="System.ComponentModel.SortDescription"></xref> structures that describes how the items in the collection are sorted in the view.
You cannot add a <xref:System.ComponentModel.SortDescription> to the returned (empty) collection because the base class <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView> does not support sorting.
Instead, use the derived classes <xref:System.Windows.Data.ListCollectionView> and <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> that do support sorting.
Also, check the <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CanSort%2A> property before adding or removing <xref:System.ComponentModel.SortDescription> objects to avoid an exception.
An empty <xref href="System.ComponentModel.SortDescriptionCollection"></xref> in all cases.
Returns the underlying unfiltered collection.
An <xref href="System.Collections.IEnumerable"></xref> object that is the underlying collection.

Gets a value that indicates whether it has been necessary to update the change log because a <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CollectionChanged"></xref> notification has been received on a different thread without first entering the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_ui](~/includes/tlasharptla-ui-md.md)] thread dispatcher.

`true` if it has been necessary to update the change log because a <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CollectionChanged"></xref> notification has been received on a different thread without first entering the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_ui](~/includes/tlasharptla-ui-md.md)] thread dispatcher; otherwise, `false`.
Returns an <xref href="System.Collections.IEnumerator"></xref> object that you can use to enumerate the items in the view.
An <xref href="System.Collections.IEnumerator"></xref> object that you can use to enumerate the items in the view.
